You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.

<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_dma_map:
```c
static int metal_uio_dev_dma_map(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				 struct linux_device *ldev,
				 uint32_t dir,
				 struct metal_sg *sg_in,
				 int nents_in,
				 struct metal_sg *sg_out)
{
	int i, j;
	void *vaddr_sg_lo, *vaddr_sg_hi, *vaddr_lo, *vaddr_hi;
	struct metal_io_region *io;

	(void)lbus;
	(void)dir;

	/* Check if the the input virt address is MMIO address */
	for (i = 0; i < nents_in; i++) {
		vaddr_sg_lo = sg_in[i].virt;
		vaddr_sg_hi = vaddr_sg_lo + sg_in[i].len;
		for (j = 0, io = ldev->device.regions;
		     j < (int)ldev->device.num_regions; j++, io++) {
			vaddr_lo = io->virt;
			vaddr_hi = vaddr_lo + io->size;
			if (vaddr_sg_lo >= vaddr_lo &&
			    vaddr_sg_hi <= vaddr_hi) {
				break;
			}
		}
		if (j == (int)ldev->device.num_regions) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
			  "%s,%s: input address isn't MMIO addr: 0x%x,%d.\n",
			__func__, ldev->dev_name, vaddr_sg_lo, sg_in[i].len);
			return -EINVAL;
		}
	}
	if (sg_out != sg_in)
		memcpy(sg_out, sg_in, nents_in*(sizeof(struct metal_sg)));
	return nents_in;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The MISRA Rule 1.2 concern is use of compiler language extensions. The only constructs in this function that rely on a known compiler extension are pointer arithmetic operations performed on void * objects (pointer +/- integer). ISO C does not allow arithmetic on void *; many compilers (e.g. GCC) treat it as an extension. Other code constructs in the function do not constitute language extensions and therefore do not need to be investigated for Rule 1.2: casts like (void)lbus and (void)dir, pointer comparisons, use of __func__, standard library calls (memcpy, metal_log), loop and indexing constructs, integer casts (e.g. (int)ldev->device.num_regions), and the return of -EINVAL are all standard C usage or project/library macros. Note: format-string/type mismatches (passing a pointer with %x) or potential runtime/semantic issues are not language extensions and are outside the scope of Rule 1.2, so they were not flagged here.
